intro: Chiranthodendron platanoides, commonly known as the Mexican flame tree, is a tropical tree native to Central America and parts of the Caribbean. It belongs to the Bignoniaceae family and is characterized by its striking orange-red flowers that bloom in clusters during the dry season. The plant has palmate leaves with five to seven leaflets, and its bark is smooth and often grayish in color. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular ornamental tree in warm climates. The flowers attract various pollinators, including bees and birds, contributing to its ecological importance.
